Problem Statement:
A one-dimensional simple harmonic oscillator is subjected to a small perturbing potential $\delta V(x)$, producing a "dimple" at the center of the motion. Thus

$$
H=\frac{P^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} x^{2}+\frac{\lambda}{x^{2}+a^{2}}=\frac{P^{2}}{2 m}+V+\delta V .
$$

Calculate the correction to the ground state energy of the oscillator to first order in $\lambda$ in the event that

$a \gg \sqrt{\hbar / m \omega}$.

Hints: the normalized ground state wave function of a simple harmonic oscillator is

and

$$
\psi_{0}(x)=\left(\frac{m \omega}{\pi \hbar}\right)^{1 / 4} \exp \left(-m \omega x^{2} / 2 \hbar\right)
$$

$$
\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{d x}{x^{2}+a^{2}}=\frac{\pi}{a}
$$
Solution:
The energy correction for the ground state given by first order perturbation is

$$
\Delta E=\langle 0|\delta V| 0\rangle=\lambda\left(\frac{m \omega}{\pi \hbar}\right)^{1 / 2} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{e^{-m \omega x^{2} / \hbar}}{x^{2}+a^{2}} d x .
$$

$a \ll \sqrt{\hbar / m \omega}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta E &=\lambda\left(\frac{m \omega}{\pi \hbar}\right)^{1 / 2} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{e^{-m \omega a^{2} y^{2} / \hbar}}{a\left(y^{2}+1\right)} d y \\
& \approx \frac{\lambda}{a}\left(\frac{m \omega}{\pi \hbar}\right)^{1 / 2} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{d y}{y^{2}+1}=\frac{\lambda}{a} \sqrt{\frac{m \omega \pi}{\hbar}} .
\end{aligned}
$$$a \gg \sqrt{\hbar / m \omega}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta E &=\frac{\lambda}{a}\left(\frac{m \omega}{\pi \hbar}\right)^{1 / 2} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{e^{-m \omega a^{2} y^{2} / \hbar}}{y^{2}+1} d y \\
& \approx \frac{\lambda}{a}\left(\frac{m \omega}{\pi \hbar}\right)^{1 / 2} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} e^{-m \omega a^{2} y^{2} / \hbar} d y=\lambda / a^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Problem Statement:
Consider the one-dimensional motion of an uncharged particle of spin $1 / 2$ and magnetic moment $\mu=-2 \mu_{0} \mathrm{~s} / \hbar$. The particle is confined in an infinite square well extending from $x=-L$ to $x=L$. In region I $(x<0)$ there is a uniform magnetic field in the $z$ direction $\mathbf{B}=B_{0} \mathbf{e}_{z}$; in region II $(x>0)$ there is a uniform field of the same magnitude but pointing in the $x$ direction $\mathbf{B}=B_{0} \mathbf{e}_{x}$. Here $\mathbf{e}_{x}$ and $\mathbf{e}_{z}$ are unit vectors in the $x$ and $z$ directions.

Now consider fields with $B_{0}$ of arbitrary strength. Find the form $\psi_{\mathrm{II}}$ that the eigenfunction has in region II which satisfies the right-hand boundary condition (see the figure).
Solution:
In the absence of magnetic field, $H=H_{0}$ and the energy eigenfunctions (space part) and eigenvalues are respectively

$$
\psi_{n}=\sqrt{1 / L} \sin \frac{n \pi(x+L)}{2 L},
$$

$$
E_{n}=\frac{\pi^{2} \hbar^{2} n^{2}}{8 m L^{2}}, \quad n=1,2,3, \ldots
$$

As for the spin part, we know that each energy level has a degeneracy of 2 . When a magnetic field is present, $H=H_{0}+H^{\prime}$, where

$$
H^{\prime}=-\boldsymbol{\mu} \cdot \mathbf{B}=\frac{2 \mu_{0} \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}}{\hbar}=\mu_{0} \boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot \mathbf{B}= \begin{cases}\mu_{0} B_{0} \sigma_{z}, & -L \leq x \leq 0 \\ \mu_{0} B_{0} \sigma_{x}, & 0 \leq x \leq L \\ 0 & \text { elsewhere }\end{cases}
$$

If the field is weak, let $u_{1}=\psi_{1}(x)\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0\end{array}\right), u_{2}=\psi_{1}(x)\left(\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 1\end{array}\right)$ be the base vectors. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
H_{11}^{\prime}=&\left\langle u_{1}\left|H^{\prime}\right| u_{1}\right\rangle=\mu_{0} B_{0}\left(\begin{array}{ll}
1 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right) \\
& \times \int_{-L}^{0} \psi_{1}^{*}(x) \psi_{1}(x) d x=\frac{\mu_{0} B_{0}}{2}, \\
H_{21}^{\prime}=& H_{12}^{\prime}=\left\langle u_{1}\left|H^{\prime}\right| u_{2}\right\rangle \\
=& \mu_{0} B_{0}\left(\begin{array}{ll}
1 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & 1 \\
1 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right) \int_{0}^{L} \psi_{1}^{*}(x) \psi_{1}(x) d x=\frac{\mu_{0} B_{0}}{2}, \\
H_{22}^{\prime}=&\left\langle\mu_{2}\left|H^{\prime}\right| \mu_{2}\right\rangle \\
=&-\mu_{0} B_{0}\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 1
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{rr}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right) \int_{-L}^{0} \psi_{1}^{*}(x) \psi_{1}(x) d x=-\frac{\mu_{0} B_{0}}{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

and from det $\left(H^{\prime}-E^{(1)} I\right)=0$ we get

$$
\left(\frac{\mu_{0} B_{0}}{2}-E^{(1)}\right)\left(-\frac{\mu_{0} B_{0}}{2}-E^{(1)}\right)-\frac{\mu_{0}^{2} B_{0}^{2}}{4}=0,
$$

or

$$
E^{(1)}=\pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \mu_{0} B_{0} .
$$

The ground state energy level is therefore

$$
E_{0}=\frac{\pi^{2} \hbar^{2}}{8 m L^{2}}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \mu_{0} B_{0} .
$$

From

$$
\left(H^{\prime}-E^{(1)} I\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
0
\end{array}\right)
$$

we get the ground state wave function

$$
\varphi_{0}=a u_{1}+b u_{2}=\psi_{1}(x)\left(\begin{array}{c}
1-\sqrt{2} \\
1
\end{array}\right) . \quad \text { (unnormalized) }
$$The space part of the wave function in region $I$ is

$$
\psi_{\mathrm{I} k_{1}}= \begin{cases}A \sin k_{1}(x+L)+B \cos k_{1}(x+L), & -L \leq x \leq 0, \\ 0, & x<-L\end{cases}
$$

The continuity condition of the wave function gives $B=0$. In region I, the spin is aligned to the $z$ direction, the eigenvectors being $\left(\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 1\end{array}\right)$ for $z \downarrow$ and $\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0\end{array}\right)$ for $z \uparrow$. Hence

$$
\begin{cases}\psi_{\mathrm{I} k_{1} z \downarrow}=\sin k_{1}(x+L)\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right), & E=\frac{\hbar^{2} k_{1}^{2}}{2 m}-\mu_{0} B_{0} \\
\psi_{\mathrm{I} k_{1} z \uparrow}=\sin k_{1}(x+L)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right), & E=\frac{\hbar^{2} k_{1}^{2}}{2 m}+\mu_{0} B_{0}\end{cases}
$$

In a similar way we obtain the eigenfunctions for region II $(0 \leq x \leq L)$

$$
\begin{cases}\psi_{\mathrm{II} k_{2} x \downarrow}=\sin k_{2}(x-L)\left(\begin{array}{r}
1 \\
-1
\end{array}\right), \quad E=\frac{\hbar^{2} k_{2}^{2}}{2 m}-\mu_{0} B_{0} \\
\psi_{\mathrm{II} k_{2} x \uparrow}=\sin k_{2}(x-L)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
1
\end{array}\right), \quad E=\frac{\hbar^{2} k_{2}^{2}}{2 m}+\mu_{0} B_{0}\end{cases}
$$

Problem Statement:
Consider a one-dimensional square-well potential (see the figure):

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
V(x)=\infty, & x<0 \\
V(x)=-V_{0}, & 0<x<a \\
V(x)=0, & x>a .
\end{array}
$$

Suppose a particle with energy $E>0$ is incident upon this potential. Find the phase relation between the incident and the outgoing wave.
Solution:
The Schrödinger equations for the different regions are

$$
\begin{gathered}
{\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}-V_{0}-E\right] \psi(x)=0, \quad 0<x<a,} \\
{\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}-E\right] \psi(x)=0, \quad x>a .}
\end{gathered}
$$

$E<0$

<i> Consider first the case of $V_{0}<-E$, for which the wave function is

$$
\psi(x)= \begin{cases}0, & x<0 \\ A \sinh (k x), & 0<x<a \\ B e^{-k^{\prime} x}, & x>a\end{cases}
$$

where

$$
k=\sqrt{\frac{2 m\left(-V_{0}-E\right)}{\hbar^{2}}}, \quad k^{\prime}=\sqrt{\frac{2 m(-E)}{\hbar^{2}}} .
$$

The continuity conditions of the wave function give

$$
\begin{aligned}
A \sinh (k a) &=B e^{-k^{\prime} a} \\
A k \cosh (k a) &=-B k^{\prime} e^{-k^{\prime} a}
\end{aligned}
$$

and hence

$$
k \operatorname{coth}(k a)=-k^{\prime} \text {. }
$$

As $\operatorname{coth} x>0$ for $x>0$, there is no solution for this case.

<ii For $V_{0}>-E, i k \rightarrow k, k=\sqrt{2 m\left(V_{0}+E\right)} / \hbar$, and the equation determining the energy becomes $k \cot (k a)=-k^{\prime}$. The wave function is

$$
\psi(x)= \begin{cases}0, & x<0 \\ A \sin (k x), & 0<x<a \\ B e^{-k^{\prime} x}, & x>a\end{cases}
$$

From the continuity and normalization of the wave function we get

$$
A=\left[\frac{2}{\frac{1}{k^{\prime}} \sin ^{2}(k a)+a-\frac{1}{2 k} \sin (2 k a)}\right]^{1 / 2}
$$

$$
B=\left[\frac{2}{\frac{1}{k^{\prime}} \sin ^{2}(k a)+a-\frac{1}{2 k} \sin (2 k a)}\right]^{1 / 2} e^{k^{\prime} a} \sin (k a) .
$$$E>0$. The wave function is

$$
\psi(x)= \begin{cases}0, & x<0 \\ A \sin (k x), & 0<x<a \\ B \sin \left(k^{\prime} x+\varphi\right), & x>a\end{cases}
$$

where

$$
k=\sqrt{\frac{2 m\left(E+V_{0}\right)}{\hbar^{2}}}, \quad k^{\prime}=\sqrt{2 m E / \hbar^{2}} .
$$

As $\partial \ln \psi / \partial \ln x$ is continuous at $x=a$,

$$
(k a) \cot (k a)=\left(k^{\prime} a\right) \cot \left(k^{\prime} a+\varphi\right)
$$

whence

$$
\varphi=\operatorname{arccot}\left(\frac{k}{k^{\prime}} \cot (k a)\right)-k^{\prime} a .
$$

For $x>a$,

$$
\psi(x)=\frac{B}{2 i} e^{-i k^{\prime} x-i \varphi}-\frac{B}{2 i} e^{i k^{\prime} x+i \varphi}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\varphi_{\mathrm{inc}}(x) \propto e^{-i k^{\prime} x-i \varphi} \\
&\varphi_{\text {out }}(x) \propto e^{i k^{\prime} x+i \varphi}
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the phase shift of the outgoing wave in relation to the incident wave is

$$
\delta=2 \varphi=2\left[\operatorname{arccot}\left(\frac{k}{k^{\prime}} \cot (k a)\right)-k^{\prime} a\right] .
$$

Problem Statement:
Suppose an electron is in a state described by the wave function

$$
\psi=\frac{1}{\sqrt{4 \pi}}\left(e^{i \phi} \sin \theta+\cos \theta\right) g(r)
$$

where

$$
\int_{0}^{\infty}|g(r)|^{2} r^{2} d r=1
$$

and $\phi, \theta$ are the azimuth and polar angles respectively.

What is the expectation value of $L_{z}$ ?
Solution:
As

$$
Y_{10}=\sqrt{\frac{3}{4 \pi}} \cos \theta, Y_{1, \pm 1}=\mp \sqrt{\frac{3}{8 \pi}} \sin \theta e^{\pm i \phi},
$$

the wave function can be written as

$$
\psi=\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}}\left(-\sqrt{2} Y_{11}+Y_{10}\right) g(r)
$$

Hence the possible values of $L_{z}$ are $+\hbar, 0$.

Since

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int|\psi|^{2} d r &=\frac{1}{4 \pi} \int_{0}^{\infty}|g(r)|^{2} r^{2} d r \int_{0}^{\pi} d \theta \int_{0}^{2 \pi}(1+\cos \phi \sin 2 \theta) \sin \theta d \phi \\
&=\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{\pi} \sin \theta d \theta=1
\end{aligned}
$$

the given wave function is normalized. The probability density is then given by $P=|\psi|^{2}$. Thus the probability of $L_{z}=+\hbar$ is $\left(\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}}\right)^{2}$ or $2 / 3$ and that of $L_{z}=0$ is $\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\right)^{2}$ or $1 / 3$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int \psi^{*} L_{z} \psi r^{2} \sin \theta d \theta d \phi d r=& \int\left[\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}}\left(-\sqrt{2} Y_{11}+Y_{10}\right)\right]^{*} \\
& \times \hat{L}_{z}\left[\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}}\left(-\sqrt{2} Y_{11}+Y_{10}\right)\right] \\
& \times|g(r)|^{2} r^{2} d r \sin \theta d \theta d \phi \\
=& \frac{2}{3} \hbar \int_{0}^{\pi} d \theta \int_{0}^{2 \pi} Y_{11}^{2} d \phi=\frac{2}{3} \hbar
\end{aligned}
$$

Problem Statement: The ground state of the realistic helium atom is of course nondegenerate. However, consider a hypothetical helium atom in which the two electrons are replaced by two identical, spin-one particles of negative charge. Neglect spin-dependent forces. For this hypothetical atom, what is the degeneracy of the ground state? Give your reasoning.
Solution:
The two new particles are Bosons; thus the wave function must be symmetrical. In the ground state, the two particles must stay in 1s orbit. Then the space wave function is symmetrical, and consequently the spin wave function is symmetrical too. As $s_{1}=1$ and $s_{2}=1$, the total $S$ has three possible values:

$S=2$, the spin wave function is symmetric and its degeneracy is $2 S+1=5$.

$S=1$, the spin wave function is antisymmetric and its degeneracy is $2 S+1=3$.

$S=0$, the spin wave function is symmetric and its degeneracy is $2 S+1=1$

If the spin-dependent forces are neglected, the degeneracy of the ground state is $5+3+1=9$.

Problem Statement: Employing first order perturbation theory, calculate the energy of the first state for an infinite square well of width $a$, whose portion $\mathrm{AB}$ has been sliced off. (Note: The line $\mathrm{OA}$ is a straight line).
Solution:
The modification to the Hamiltonian, $H^{\prime}=\frac{V_{0}}{a} x(0 \leq x \leq a)$, can be considered as a perturbation. The unperturbed eigenfunctions and the corresponding eigenvalues of the first three states are

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Psi_{1}^{0} &=\sqrt{\frac{2}{a}} \sin \frac{\pi}{a} x, \quad E_{1}^{0}=\frac{\pi^{2} \hbar^{2}}{2 \mu a^{2}} ; \\
\Psi_{2}^{0} &=\sqrt{\frac{2}{a}} \sin \frac{2 \pi}{a} x, \quad E_{2}^{0}=\frac{2 \pi^{2} \hbar^{2}}{\mu a^{2}} ; \\
\Psi_{3}^{0} &=\sqrt{\frac{2}{a}} \sin \frac{3 \pi}{a} x, \quad E_{3}^{0}=\frac{9 \pi^{2} \hbar^{2}}{2 \mu a^{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The first order energy corrections are then

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left\langle\psi_{1}^{0}\left|H^{\prime}\right| \psi_{1}^{0}\right\rangle=\frac{V_{0}}{2}, \\
&\left\langle\psi_{2}^{0}\left|H^{\prime}\right| \psi_{2}^{0}\right\rangle=\frac{V_{0}}{2}, \\
&\left\langle\psi_{3}^{0}\left|H^{\prime}\right| \psi_{3}^{0}\right\rangle=\frac{V_{0}}{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

and the energies of the first three states are

$$
\frac{\pi^{2} \hbar^{2}}{2 \mu a^{2}}+\frac{V_{0}}{2}, \quad \frac{2 \pi^{2} \hbar^{2}}{\mu a^{2}}+\frac{V_{0}}{2}, \quad \frac{9 \pi^{2} \hbar^{2}}{2 \mu a^{2}}+\frac{V_{0}}{2} .
$$

Problem Statement:
Low energy neutrons from a nuclear reactor have been used to test gravitationally induced quantum interference. In the figure, neutrons incident from $\mathrm{A}$ can follow two paths of equal lengths, $\mathrm{ABCEF}$ and $\mathrm{ABDEF}$, and interfere after they recombine at $E$. The three parallel slabs which diffract the neutrons are cut from one single crystal. To change the effects of the gravitational potential energy, the system can be rotated about the line ABD. Suppose $\phi$ is the angle of this rotation $(\phi=0$ for the path ABCEF horizontal).

The neutron wavelength used in the experiment is $1.45 \AA$. What is the corresponding kinetic energy in electron volts?

Mass of neutron $=939 \mathrm{MeV} / c^{2}, \hbar c=1.97 \times 10^{-11} \mathrm{MeV} \cdot \mathrm{cm}$.
Solution:
The wave function of the incident neutrons can be taken as

$$
\psi(\mathbf{r}, t)=c e^{(i \mathbf{p} \cdot \mathbf{r}-i E t) / \hbar}
$$

where $c$ is a constant. When they move along a certain orbit from $x=0$ to $x=l$ it becomes

$$
\psi(\mathbf{r}, t)=c \exp \left[\frac{i}{\hbar} \int_{0}^{l} \sqrt{2 m(E-V)} d x-\frac{i}{\hbar} E t\right]
$$

Thus the phase is

$$
\varphi=\frac{1}{\hbar} \int_{0}^{l} \sqrt{2 m(E-V)} d x-\frac{1}{\hbar} E t
$$

The neutrons are separated at point $B$ into two beams 1 and 2 , for which $\varphi_{B_{1}}=\varphi_{B_{2}}$.

The situations on lines $\mathrm{BC}$ and $\mathrm{DE}$ are same and so for the two neutron beams, $\Delta \varphi_{C B}=\Delta \varphi_{E D}$. On line $\mathrm{BD}$, we can set the gravitational potential $V=0, E=E_{0}$, and so

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta \varphi_{D B} &=\frac{1}{\hbar} \int_{0}^{S} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}} d x-\frac{1}{\hbar} E_{0} \cdot \frac{S}{v_{0}} \\
&=\frac{1}{\hbar}\left(\sqrt{2 m E_{0}} S-\frac{1}{2} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}} S\right)=\frac{S}{2 \hbar} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $v_{0}$ is the neutron velocity $\frac{1}{m} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}$.

On line CE, the gravitational potential is

$$
V=m g h=m g \cdot \overline{B E} \sin \theta \sin \phi, \quad \text { with } \overline{B E}=2 S \cos \theta
$$

i.e.,

$$
V=m g S \sin 2 \theta \sin \phi
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta \varphi_{E C} &=\frac{1}{\hbar} \int_{0}^{S} \sqrt{2 m\left(E_{0}-V\right)} d x-\frac{1}{\hbar} E_{0} t \\
&=\frac{S}{\hbar} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}} \sqrt{1-\frac{V}{E_{0}}}-\frac{1}{\hbar} E_{0} \frac{S}{\sqrt{\frac{2\left(E_{0}-V\right)}{m}}} \\
&=S \frac{\sqrt{2 m E_{0}}}{2 \hbar}\left(2 \sqrt{1-\frac{V}{E_{0}}}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{V}{E_{0}}}}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus the phase difference of the two beams of neutrons at point $F$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\beta &=\Delta \varphi_{D B}-\Delta \varphi_{E C}=\frac{S}{2 \hbar} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}\left(1-2 \sqrt{1-\frac{V}{E_{0}}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{V}{E_{0}}}}\right) \\
& \approx \frac{S}{2 \hbar} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}\left[1-2\left(1-\frac{V}{2 E_{0}}\right)+\left(1+\frac{V}{2 E_{0}}\right)\right] \\
&=\frac{3 V S}{4 \hbar E_{0}} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}
\end{aligned}
$$

as $V \ll E_{0}$. Thus

$$
\beta=q \sin \phi,
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
q & \approx \frac{3}{2} \frac{m^{2} g}{\hbar \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}} S^{2} \sin 2 \theta \\
&=K \lambda S^{2} \sin 2 \theta
\end{aligned}
$$

with

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lambda &=\frac{2 \pi \hbar}{p}=\frac{2 \pi \hbar}{\sqrt{2 m E_{0}}} \\
K &=\frac{3}{4} \frac{m^{2} g}{\pi \hbar^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$The neutron has momentum

$$
p=\frac{h}{\lambda}=\frac{2 \pi \hbar}{\lambda}
$$

and hence kinetic energy

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{k} &=\frac{p^{2}}{2 m}=\frac{2}{m c^{2}}\left(\frac{\pi \hbar c}{\lambda}\right)^{2} \\
&=\frac{2}{939 \times 10^{6}}\left(\frac{\pi \times 1.97 \times 10^{-5}}{1.45 \times 10^{-8}}\right)^{2} \\
&=0.039 \mathrm{eV}
\end{aligned}
$$

Problem Statement:
An electron is confined in the ground state of a one-dimensional harmonic oscillator such that $\sqrt{\left\langle(x-\langle x\rangle)^{2}\right\rangle}=10^{-10} \mathrm{~m}$. Find the energy (in $\mathrm{eV})$ required to excite it to its first excited state.

[Hint: The virial theorem can help.]
Solution:
The virial theorem for a one-dimensional harmonic oscillator states that $\langle T\rangle=\langle V\rangle$. Thus $E_{0}=\langle H\rangle=\langle T\rangle+\langle V\rangle=2\langle V\rangle=m_{e} \omega^{2}\left\langle x^{2}\right\rangle$, or, for the ground state,

$$
\frac{\hbar \omega}{2}=m_{e} \omega^{2}\left\langle x^{2}\right\rangle,
$$

giving

$$
\omega=\frac{\hbar}{2 m_{e}\left\langle x^{2}\right\rangle} .
$$

As $\langle x\rangle=0$ for a harmonic oscillator, we have

$$
\sqrt{\left\langle(x-\langle x\rangle)^{2}\right\rangle}=\sqrt{\left\langle x^{2}\right\rangle-\langle x\rangle^{2}}=\sqrt{\left\langle x^{2}\right\rangle}=10^{-10} \mathrm{~m} .
$$

The energy required to excite the electron to its first excited state is therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta E=\hbar \omega &=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m_{e}\left\langle x^{2}\right\rangle}=\frac{\hbar^{2} c^{2}}{2 m_{e} c^{2}\left\langle x^{2}\right\rangle} \\
&=\frac{\left(6.58 \times 10^{-16}\right)^{2} \times\left(3 \times 10^{8}\right)^{2}}{2 \times 0.51 \times 10^{-20}}=3.8 \mathrm{eV} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Problem Statement:
Consider a one-dimensional oscillator with the Hamiltonian

$$
H=p^{2} / 2 m+m \omega^{2} x^{2} / 2 .
$$

Find the time dependence of the expectation values of the "initial position" operator

$$
\begin{aligned}
&x_{0}=x \cos \omega t-(p / m \omega) \sin \omega t \\
\end{aligned}
$$
Solution:
Making use of the relation

$$
\frac{d f}{d t}=\frac{1}{i \hbar}[f, H]+\frac{\partial f}{\partial t},
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d\left\langle x_{0}\right\rangle}{d t}=& \frac{1}{i \hbar}[\langle x\rangle \cos \omega t, H]-\omega\langle x\rangle \sin \omega t \\
&-\frac{1}{i \hbar}\left[\frac{\langle p\rangle}{m \omega} \sin \omega t, H\right]-\frac{\langle p\rangle}{m} \cos \omega t \\
=& \frac{1}{i \hbar} \overline{[x, H]} \cos \omega t-\omega\langle x\rangle \sin \omega t \\
&-\frac{1}{m \omega} \frac{1}{i \hbar} \frac{1}{[p, H]} \sin \omega t-\frac{1}{m}\langle p\rangle \cos \omega t=0
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d\left\langle p_{0}\right\rangle}{d t}=& \frac{1}{i \hbar}[\langle p\rangle \cos \omega t, H]-\langle p\rangle \omega \sin \omega t \\
&+\frac{1}{i \hbar}[m \omega\langle x\rangle \sin \omega t, H]+m \omega^{2}\langle x\rangle \cos \omega t \\
=& \frac{1}{i \hbar} \overline{[p, H]} \cos \omega t-\omega\langle p\rangle \sin \omega t \\
&+\frac{m \omega}{i \hbar} \overline{[x, H]} \sin \omega t+m \omega^{2}\langle x\rangle \cos \omega t=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus the expectation values of these operators are independent of time.

Problem Statement:
Consider a spinless particle represented by the wave function

$$
\psi=K(x+y+2 z) e^{-\alpha r}
$$

where $r=\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}$, and $K$ and $\alpha$ are real constants.

What is the total angular momentum of the particle?

You may find the following expressions for the first few spherical harmonics useful:

$$
\begin{aligned}
&Y_{0}^{0}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{4 \pi}}, \quad Y_{1}^{\pm 1}=\mp \sqrt{\frac{3}{8 \pi}} \sin \theta e^{\pm i \phi}, \\
&Y_{1}^{0}=\sqrt{\frac{3}{4 \pi}} \cos \theta, \quad Y_{2}^{\pm 1}=\mp \sqrt{\frac{15}{8 \pi}} \sin \theta \cos \theta e^{\pm i \phi} .
\end{aligned}
$$
Solution:
The wave function may be rewritten in spherical coordinates as

$$
\psi=K r(\cos \phi \sin \theta+\sin \phi \sin \theta+2 \cos \theta) e^{-\alpha r}
$$

its angular part being

$$
\psi(\theta, \phi)=K^{\prime}(\cos \phi \sin \theta+\sin \phi \sin \theta+2 \cos \theta),
$$

where $K^{\prime}$ is the normalization constant such that

$$
K^{\prime 2} \int_{\theta}^{\pi} d \theta \int_{0}^{2 \pi} \sin \theta(\cos \phi \sin \theta+\sin \phi \sin \theta+2 \cos \theta)^{2} d \phi=1 \text {. }
$$

Since

$$
\cos \phi=\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{i \phi}+e^{-i \phi}\right), \quad \sin \phi=\frac{1}{2 i}\left(e^{i \phi}-e^{-i \phi}\right)
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(\theta, \phi) &=K^{\prime}\left[\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{i \phi}+e^{-i \phi}\right) \sin \theta+\frac{1}{2 i}\left(e^{i \phi}-e^{-i \phi}\right) \sin \theta+\cos 2 \theta\right], \\
&=K^{\prime}\left[-\frac{1}{2}(1-i) \sqrt{\frac{8 \pi}{3}} Y_{1}^{1}+\frac{1}{2}(1+i) \sqrt{\frac{8 \pi}{3}} Y_{1}^{-1}+2 \sqrt{\frac{4 \pi}{3}} Y_{1}^{0}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

The normalization condition and the orthonormality of $Y_{l}^{m}$ then give

$$
K^{\prime 2}\left[\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{8 \pi}{3}+\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{8 \pi}{3}+4 \cdot \frac{4 \pi}{3}\right]=1
$$

or

$$
K^{\prime}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{8 \pi}},
$$

and thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(\theta, \phi)=& \sqrt{\frac{1}{8 \pi}}\left[-\frac{1}{2}(1-i) \sqrt{\frac{8 \pi}{3}} Y_{1}^{1}\right.\\
&\left.+\frac{1}{2}(1+i) \sqrt{\frac{8 \pi}{3}} Y_{1}^{-1}+2 \sqrt{\frac{4 \pi}{3}} Y_{1}^{0}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

The total angular momentum of the particle is

$$
\sqrt{\left\langle\mathbf{L}^{2}\right\rangle}=\sqrt{l(l+1)} \hbar=\sqrt{2} \hbar .
$$

as the wave function corresponds to $l=1$.

Problem Statement:
Suppose an atom is initially in an excited ${ }^{1} S_{0}$ state (first figure) and subsequently decays into a lower, short-lived ${ }^{1} P_{1}$ state with emission of a photon $\gamma_{1}$ (second figure). Soon after, it decays into the ${ }^{1} S_{0}$ ground state by emitting a second photon $\gamma_{2}$ (third figure). Let $\theta$ be the angle between the two emitted photons.

What is the relative probability of $\theta$ in this process?

It may be of some help to know the rotation matrices $d_{m^{\prime} m}$, which relate one angular momentum representation in one coordinate system to another angular momentum representation in a rotated coordinate system, given below:

$$
\begin{array}{cccc}
m=1 & m=0 & m=-1 \\
m^{\prime}=1
\end{array}\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\frac{1+\cos \alpha}{2} & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \alpha & \frac{1-\cos \alpha}{2} \\
\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \alpha & \cos \alpha & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \alpha \\
\frac{1-\cos \alpha}{2} & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \alpha & \frac{1+\cos \alpha}{2}
\end{array}\right)
$$

where $\alpha$ is the angle between the $z$-axis of one system and the $z^{\prime}$-axis of the other.
Solution:
The atom is initially in the excited state ${ }^{1} S_{0}$. Thus the projection of the atomic angular momentum on an arbitrary $z$ direction is $L_{z}=0$. We can take the direction of the first photon emission as the $z$ direction. After the emission of the photon and the atom goes into the ${ }^{1} P_{1}$ state, if the angular momentum of that photon is $L_{z}=\pm \hbar$, correspondingly the angular momentum of the atomic state ${ }^{1} P_{1}$ is $L_{z}=\mp \hbar$, i.e., $m_{z}=\mp 1$. If we let the direction of emission of the second photon be the $z^{\prime}$-axis the projection of the eigenstate of the $z$-component of angular momentum on the $z^{\prime}$ direction is equivalent to multiplying the initial state with the $d_{m^{\prime} m}$ matrix. Only atoms that are in states $m_{z}^{\prime}=\pm 1$ can emit photon (as $L_{z}^{\prime}=\pm \hbar$ must be satisfied) in $z^{\prime}$ direction and make the atom decay into the ${ }^{1} S_{0}$ state $\left(m_{z}^{\prime}=0\right)$. Then the transitions are from $m=\pm 1$ to $m^{\prime}=\pm 1$, and we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& C_{1}=\left\langle m_{z^{\prime}}=-1\left|d_{m^{\prime} m}\right| m_{z}=+1\right\rangle \\
& =(0,0,1)\left(\begin{array}{ccc}\frac{1+\cos \theta}{2} & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta & \frac{1-\cos \theta}{2} \\\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta & \cos \theta & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta \\\frac{1-\cos \theta}{2} & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta & \frac{1+\cos \theta}{2}\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\0 \\0\end{array}\right) \\
& =\frac{1-\cos \theta}{2}, \\
& C_{2}=\left\langle m_{z^{\prime}}=+1\left|d_{m^{\prime} m}\right| m_{z}=+1\right\rangle \\
& =(1,0,0)\left(\begin{array}{ccc}\frac{1+\cos \theta}{2} & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta & \frac{1-\cos \theta}{2} \\\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta & \cos \theta & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta \\\frac{1-\cos \theta}{2} & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta & \frac{1+\cos \theta}{2}\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\0 \\0\end{array}\right) \\
& =\frac{1+\cos \theta}{2}, \\
& C_{3}=\left\langle m_{z^{\prime}}=+1\left|d_{m^{\prime} m}\right| m_{z}=-1\right\rangle=\frac{1-\cos \theta}{2}, \\
& C_{4}=\left\langle m_{z^{\prime}}=-1\left|d_{m^{\prime} m}\right| m_{z}=-1\right\rangle=\frac{1+\cos \theta}{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The relative probability of $\theta$ is

$$
P(\theta) \propto\left|C_{1}\right|^{2}+\left|C_{2}\right|^{2}+\left|C_{3}\right|^{2}+\left|C_{4}\right|^{2}=1+\cos ^{2} \theta .
$$

\end{aligned}

Problem Statement: A charged oscillating (nearly) classical system is losing energy by radiation. At energy $E$ it is radiating (and oscillating) at frequency $\nu(E)=$ $\alpha\left(E / E_{0}\right)^{-\beta}$, where $\alpha, \beta$ and $E_{0}$ are positive constants. Solution:

$$
\nu_{q u}=\tau \frac{\partial H}{\partial J},
$$

where $J=n h, \tau=n-m$, and $m, n \gg 1$. We have, with $\tau=1$,

$$
h \nu=\frac{d E}{d n}=h \alpha\left(E / E_{0}\right)^{-\beta},
$$

or

$$
E^{\beta} d E=h \alpha E_{0}^{\beta} d n .
$$

Integrating

$$
\int_{0}^{E_{n}} E^{\beta} d E=h \alpha E_{0}^{\beta} \int_{0}^{n} d n
$$

we have

$$
E_{n}=\left[h \alpha(\beta+1) n E_{0}^{\beta}\right]^{\frac{1}{1+\beta}} .
$$

Problem Statement:
If $\left|\psi_{q}\right\rangle$ is any eigenstate of the electric charge operator $Q$ corresponding to eigenvalue $q$, that is to say,

$$
Q\left|\psi_{q}\right\rangle=q\left|\psi_{q}\right\rangle
$$

the "charge conjugation" operator $C$ applied to $\left|\psi_{q}\right\rangle$ leads to an eigenstate $\left|\psi_{-q}\right\rangle$ of $Q$ corresponding to eigenvalue $-q$ :

$$
C\left|\psi_{q}\right\rangle=\left|\psi_{-q}\right\rangle .
$$

Find the eigenvalues of the operator $C Q+Q C$.
Solution:
Let

$$
|\psi\rangle=\sum_{q} c_{q}\left|\psi_{q}\right\rangle
$$

Then

$$
(C Q+Q C)\left|\psi_{q}\right\rangle=q C\left|\psi_{q}\right\rangle+Q\left|\psi_{-q}\right\rangle=q\left|\psi_{-q}\right\rangle-q\left|\psi_{-q}\right\rangle=0
$$

Thus the eigenvalue of the operator $C Q+Q C$ is zero.

Problem Statement:
A rigid body with moment of inertia of $I_{z}$ rotates freely in the $x-y$ plane. Let $\phi$ be the angle between the $x$-axis and the rotator axis.

Find the energy eigenvalues.
Solution:
The Hamiltonian of a plane rotator is

$$
H=-\left(\hbar^{2} / 2 I_{z}\right) d^{2} / d \phi^{2}
$$

and so the Schrödinger equation is

$$
-\left(\hbar^{2} / 2 I_{z}\right) d^{2} \psi / d \phi^{2}=E \psi \text {. }
$$

Setting $\alpha^{2}=2 I_{z} E / \hbar^{2}$, we write the solution as

$$

$$

where $A, B$ are arbitrary constants. For the wave function to be singlevalued, i.e. $\psi(\phi)=\psi(\phi+2 \pi)$, we require

$$
\alpha \equiv m=0, \quad \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots .
$$

The eigenvalues of energy are then

$$
E_{m}=m^{2} \hbar^{2} / 2 I_{z}, \quad m=0, \pm 1, \ldots
$$

and the corresponding eigenfunctions are

$$
\psi_{m}(\phi)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} e^{i m \phi}, \quad m=0, \pm 1, \ldots,
$$

after normalization $\int_{0}^{2 \pi} \psi_{m}^{*} \psi_{m} d \phi=1$

Problem Statement: The first excited state of $\mathrm{Mg}$ has the configuration $(3 s, 3 p)$ for the valence electrons. In the LS-coupling limit, which values of $L$ and $S$ are possible? What is the form of the spatial part of their wave functions using the single-particle functions $\psi_{s}(\mathbf{r})$ and $\phi_{p}(\mathbf{r})$ ? Which will have the lowest energy?
Solution:
$\psi(1,2)$ must satisfy the condition of antisymmetry for interchange of the two particles:

$$
\hat{P}_{12} \psi(1,2)=\psi(2,1)=-\psi(1,2) .
$$

In an atom, if there are two electrons having identical quantum numbers then $\psi(1,2)=\psi(2,1)$. The antisymmetry condition above then gives $\psi(1,2)=0$, implying that such a state does not exist.

The electron configuration $(3 s, 3 p)$ correspond to

$$
\begin{aligned}
&l_{1}=0, \quad l_{2}=1 \\
&s_{1}=s_{2}=1 / 2
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{gathered}
L=1, \quad S=0,1 \\
\psi_{S}^{L}(1,2)=\phi_{S}^{L}(1,2) \chi_{S}(1,2)
\end{gathered}
$$

where

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
\phi_{0}^{1}(1,2) &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\phi_{s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \phi_{p}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)+\phi_{s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right) \phi_{p}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right)\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(1+\hat{P}_{12}\right) \phi_{s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \phi_{p}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right) \\
\phi_{1}^{1}(1,2) &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(1-\hat{P}_{12}\right) \phi_{s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \phi_{p}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

The lowest energy state is $\Psi_{1}^{1}(1,2)$, i.e. the state of $S=1$. Because the spatial part of the state $S=1$ is antisymmetric for the interchange $1 \leftrightarrow 2$, the probability that the two electrons get close together is small, and so the Coulomb repulsive energy is small, resulting in a lower total energy.

Problem Statement:
A diatomic molecule with equally massive atoms, each with mass $M$, separated by $D$ is electrically polarized, rotating about an axis perpendicular to $D$ and running through the center of mass of the molecule.

Determine the frequency of the electric dipole radiation emitted from the rotating molecule as a function of $J$.

$$

$$
\begin{aligned}

=& \sqrt{\frac{\left(J^{\prime}+1-m^{\prime}\right)\left(J^{\prime}+1+m^{\prime}\right)}{\left(2 J^{\prime}+1\right)\left(2 J^{\prime}+3\right)}} \delta_{J^{\prime \prime}, J^{\prime}+1} \delta_{m^{\prime \prime} m^{\prime}} \\
&+\sqrt{\frac{\left(J^{\prime}+m^{\prime}\right)\left(J^{\prime}-m^{\prime}\right)}{\left(2 J^{\prime}+1\right)\left(2 J^{\prime}-1\right)} \delta_{J^{\prime \prime}, J^{\prime}-1} \delta_{m^{\prime \prime} m^{\prime}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

we require

\begin{gathered}
\Delta J=j^{\prime \prime}-j^{\prime}=\pm 1 \\
\Delta m=m^{\prime \prime}-m^{\prime}=0 .
\end{gathered}
$$For the transition from energy level $J$ to $J-1$, we have

$$
\hbar \omega=E_{J}-E_{J-1}=\frac{1}{M D^{2}} J(J+1) \hbar^{2}-\frac{1}{M D^{2}}(J-1) J \hbar^{2}=\frac{2 J \hbar^{2}}{M D^{2}},
$$

giving

$$
\omega=\frac{2 J \hbar}{M D^{2}} .
$$

Problem Statement:
A perfectly elastic ball is bouncing between two parallel walls.

Using classical mechanics, calculate the change in energy per unit time of the ball as the walls are slowly and uniformly moved closer together.
Solution:
In classical mechanics, the energy of the ball is

$$
E=\frac{p^{2}}{2 m},
$$

so $\frac{d E}{d t}=\frac{p}{m} \frac{d p}{d t}$.

At a certain instant $t$, the walls are separated by $L$ and the ball moves to the right with speed $v_{2}^{\prime}$. Because the collision is perfectly elastic, the speed of the ball relative to the right wall before and after bouncing from it remains the same:

$$
v_{2}^{\prime}+v_{1}=v_{2}+\left(-v_{1}\right),
$$

where $v_{2}$ is the speed of the ball after bouncing. Thus,

$$
\begin{gathered}
v_{2}^{\prime}-v_{2}=-2 v_{1} \\
\Delta p=m\left(v_{2}^{\prime}-v_{2}\right)=-2 m v_{1} \\
d E / d t=\frac{p}{m} \frac{d p}{d t} \approx \frac{p}{m} \frac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=-\frac{p}{m} 2 m v_{1} \cdot \frac{v_{2}}{2 L}=-\frac{p v_{1} v_{2}}{L}
\end{gathered}
$$

where $\Delta t=\frac{2 L}{v_{2}}$ is the time interval between two successive collisions. As the right wall moves very slowly,

$$
\begin{aligned}
d E / d t &=-\frac{p v_{2}}{L} v_{1}=-\frac{p}{L} \cdot \frac{p}{m} \cdot \frac{d L}{d t} \\
&=-\frac{2}{L} \cdot \frac{p^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d L}{d t}=-\frac{2 E}{L} \frac{d L}{d t}
\end{aligned}
$$

which is the rate of change of the energy of the ball according to classical mechanics.

Problem Statement:
The deuteron is a bound state of a proton and a neutron of total angular momentum $J=1$. It is known to be principally an $S(L=0)$ state with a small admixture of a $D(L=2)$ state.

Calculate the magnetic moment of the pure $D$ state $n-p$ system with $J=1$. Assume that the $n$ and $p$ spins are to be coupled to make the total spin $S$ which is then coupled to the orbital angular momentum $L$ to give the total angular momentum $J$. Express your result in nuclear magnetons. The proton and neutron magnetic moments are $2.79$ and $-1.91$ nuclear magnetons respectively.

$(C U S)$
Solution:
The parities of the $S$ and $D$ states are positive, while the parity of the $P$ state is negative. Because of the conservation of parity in strong interaction, a quantum state that is initially an $S$ state cannot have a $P$ state component at any later moment.

The possible spin values for a system composed of a proton and a neutron are 1 and 0 . We are given $\mathbf{J}=\mathbf{L}+\mathbf{S}$ and $J=1$. If $S=0, L=1$, the system would be in a $P$ state, which must be excluded as we have seen in (a). The allowed values are then $S=1, L=2,1,0$. Therefore a $G$ state $(L=4)$ cannot contribute.

The total spin is $\mathbf{S}=\mathbf{s}_{p}+\mathbf{s}_{n}$. For a pure $D$ state with $J=1$, the orbital angular momentum (relative to the center of mass of the $n$ and $p$ ) is $L=2$ and the total spin must be $S=1$. The total magnetic moment arises from the coupling of the magnetic moment of the total spin, $\mu$, with that of the orbital angular momentum, $\boldsymbol{\mu}_{L}$, where $\boldsymbol{\mu}=\boldsymbol{\mu}_{p}+\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n}, \boldsymbol{\mu}_{p}, \boldsymbol{\mu}_{n}$ being the spin magnetic moments of $p$ and $n$ respectively.

The average value of the component of $\mu$ in the direction of the total spin $\mathbf{S}$ is

$$
\mu_{s}=\frac{\left(g_{p} \mu_{N} \mathbf{s}_{p}+g_{n} \mu_{N} \mathbf{s}_{n}\right) \cdot \mathbf{S}}{\mathbf{S}^{2}} \mathbf{S}=\frac{1}{2}\left(g_{p}+g_{n}\right) \mu_{N} \mathbf{S}
$$

where

$$
\mu_{N}=\frac{e \hbar}{2 m_{p} c}, \quad g_{p}=5.58, \quad g_{n}=-3.82,
$$

as $\mathbf{s}_{p}=\mathbf{s}_{n}=\frac{1}{2} \mathbf{S}$.

The motion of the proton relative to the center of mass gives rise to a magnetic moment, while the motion of the neutron does not as it is uncharged. Thus

$$
\mu_{L}=\mu_{N} \mathbf{L}_{p},
$$

where $\mathbf{L}_{p}$ is the angular momentum of the proton relative to the center of mass. As $\mathbf{L}_{p}+\mathbf{L}_{n}=\mathbf{L}$ and we may assume $\mathbf{L}_{p}=\mathbf{L}_{n}$, we have $\mathbf{L}_{p}=\mathbf{L} / 2$ (the center of mass is at the mid-point of the connecting line, taking $m_{p} \approx m_{n}$ ). Consequently, $\mu_{L}=\mu_{N} \mathbf{L} / 2$.

The total coupled magnetic moment along the direction of $\mathbf{J}$ is then

$$
\mu_{T}=\frac{\left[\frac{1}{2} \mu_{N} \mathbf{L} \cdot \mathbf{J}+\frac{1}{2}\left(g_{p}+g_{n}\right) \mu_{N} \mathbf{S} \cdot \mathbf{J}\right] \mathbf{J}}{J(J+1)} .
$$

Since $\mathbf{J}=\mathbf{L}+\mathbf{S}, \mathbf{S} \cdot \mathbf{L}=\frac{1}{2}\left(J^{2}-L^{2}-S^{2}\right)$. With $J=1, L=2, S=1$ and so $J^{2}=2, L^{2}=6, S^{2}=2$, we have $\mathbf{S} \cdot \mathbf{L}=-3$ and thus $\mathbf{L} \cdot \mathbf{J}=3$, $\mathbf{S} \cdot \mathbf{J}=-1$. Hence 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{\mu}_{T} &=\left[\frac{1}{2} \mu_{N} \cdot 3+\frac{1}{2}\left(g_{p}+g_{n}\right) \mu_{N}(-1)\right] \mathbf{J} / 2 \\
&=\left[1.5-\frac{1}{2}\left(g_{p}+g_{n}\right)\right] \frac{1}{2} \mu_{N} \mathbf{J}=0.31 \mu_{N} \mathbf{J} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Taking the direction of $\mathbf{J}$ as the $z$-axis and letting $J_{z}$ take the maximum value $J_{z}=1$, we have $\mu_{T}=0.31 \mu_{N}$.

Problem Statement:
A particle of mass $m$ is interacting in three dimensions with a spherically symmetric potential of the form $V(\mathbf{r})=-C \delta(|\mathbf{r}|-a)$.

In other words, the potential is a delta function that vanishes unless the particle is precisely a distance " $a$ " from the center of the potential. Here $C$ is a positive constant.

Find the minimum value of $C$ for which there is bound state.
Solution:
Suppose the eigenfunction of a bound state of the single-particle system has the form

$$
\psi(\mathbf{r})=R(r) Y_{l m}(\theta, \varphi) .
$$

Then the radial function $R(r)$ satisfies

$$

If the $z$-component of angular momentum, $L_{z}$, were measured, what is the probability that the result would be $L_{z}=+\hbar$ ?

$$

\end{aligned}

$$

$$

$$

we have

\begin{aligned}

\end{aligned}

$$
K^{\prime 2}\left[\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{8 \pi}{3}+\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{8 \pi}{3}+4 \cdot \frac{4 \pi}{3}\right]=1
$$

or

$$

and thus

$$
\begin{aligned}

Problem Statement:
For a particle of mass $m$ in a one-dimensional box of length $l$, the eigenfunctions and energies are

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi_{n}(x) &=\sqrt{\frac{2}{l}} \sin \frac{n \pi x}{l}, \quad 0 \leq x \leq l \\
E_{n} &=\frac{1}{2 m}\left(\frac{n \pi \hbar}{l}\right)^{2}, \quad n=\pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots
\end{aligned}
$$

Suppose the particle is originally in a state $|n\rangle$ and the box length is increased to a length of $2 l(0 \leq x \leq 2 l)$ in a time $t \ll h / E_{n}$. Afterwards what is the probability that the particle will be found in an energy eigenstate with energy $E_{n}$ ?
Solution:
First consider the process in which the box length is increased from $l$ to $2 l$. As $t \ll \frac{h}{E_{n}}$, it is reasonable to assume that the state of the particle in the box is unable to respond to the change during such a short time. Therefore the wave function of the particle after the change is completed is

$$
\psi(x)= \begin{cases}\sqrt{\frac{2}{l}} \sin \frac{n \pi x}{l}, & 0 \leq x \leq l \\ 0, & l \leq x \leq 2 l\end{cases}
$$

On the other hand, the eigenstates and eigenvalues of the same particle in the one-dimensional box of length $2 l$ would be, respectively,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\phi_{n^{\prime}}(x) &=\sqrt{\frac{1}{l}} \sin \frac{n^{\prime} \pi x}{2 l}, \quad(0 \leq x \leq 2 l), \\
E_{n^{\prime}} &=\frac{1}{2 m}\left(\frac{n^{\prime} \pi \hbar}{2 l}\right)^{2}, \quad\left(n^{\prime}=\pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

The energy $E_{n}$ of the particle corresponds to the energy level $E_{n^{\prime}}$ in the $2 l$ box, where $\frac{n}{l}=\frac{n^{\prime}}{2 l}$, i.e., $n^{\prime}=2 n$. The corresponding eigenstate is then $\phi_{2 n}$. Thus the probability amplitude is

$$
A=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \phi_{2 n}(x) \psi(x) d x=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{l} \int_{0}^{l} \sin ^{2} \frac{n \pi x}{l} d x, \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}},
$$

and the probability of finding the particle in an eigenstate with energy $E_{n}$ is

$$
P=|A|^{2}=\frac{1}{2} .
$$

Problem Statement: A particle of mass $m$ moves non-relativistically in one dimension in a potential given by $V(x)=-a \delta(x)$, where $\delta(x)$ is the usual Dirac delta function. Solution:
For bound states, $E<0$. The Schrödinger equation

$$
\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}-a \delta(x)\right] \psi(x)=E \psi(x)
$$

has for $x \neq 0$ the solutions finite at $x=\pm \infty$ as follows,

$$
\psi(x)= \begin{cases}A e^{k x} & \text { for } x<0 \\ A e^{-k x} & \text { for } x>0\end{cases}
$$

where $k=\frac{\sqrt{-2 m E}}{\hbar}$ and $A$ is an arbitrary constant. Applying $\lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0^{+}}$ $\int_{-\varepsilon}^{\varepsilon} d x$ to the Schrödinger equation gives

$$
\psi^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)-\psi^{\prime}\left(0^{-}\right)=-\frac{2 m a}{\hbar^{2}} \psi(0)
$$

since

$$
\int_{-\varepsilon}^{\varepsilon} \psi(x) \delta(x) d x=\psi(0), \quad \lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0} \int_{-\varepsilon}^{\varepsilon} \psi(x) d x=0
$$

for finite $\psi(0)$. Substitution of $\psi(x)$ in (1) gives

$$
k=\frac{m a}{\hbar^{2}} .
$$

Hence

$$
\psi(x)=A \exp \left(-\frac{m a|x|}{\hbar^{2}}\right)
$$

On account of symmetry, the probabilities are

$$
\begin{aligned}
P\left(|x|<x_{0}\right) &=2|A|^{2} \int_{0}^{x_{0}} e^{-2 k x} d x=\frac{|A|^{2}}{k}\left(1-e^{-2 k x_{0}}\right), \\
P(-\infty<x<\infty) &=2|A|^{2} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-2 k x} d x=\frac{|A|^{2}}{k}
\end{aligned}
$$

As it is given

$$
1-e^{-2 k x_{0}}=\frac{1}{2},
$$

we have

$$
x_{0}=\frac{1}{2 k} \ln 2=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m a} \ln 2 .
$$

Problem Statement:
At time $t=0$ a particle in the potential $V(x)=m \omega^{2} x^{2} / 2$ is described by the wave function

$$
\psi(x, 0)=A \sum_{n}(1 / \sqrt{2})^{n} \psi_{n}(x)
$$

where $\psi_{n}(x)$ are eigenstates of the energy with eigenvalues $E_{n}=(n+$ 1/2) $\hbar \omega$. You are given that $\left(\psi_{n}, \psi_{n^{\prime}}\right)=\delta_{n n^{\prime}}$.

Find the expectation value of the energy at $t=0$.
Solution:
The normalization condition

$$
\begin{aligned}
(\psi(x, 0), \psi(x, 0)) &=|A|^{2} \sum_{m, n}(1 / 2)^{(m+n) / 2}\left(\psi_{n}, \psi_{m}\right) \\
&=|A|^{2} \sum_{m}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{m}=2|A|^{2}=1
\end{aligned}
$$

gives $A=1 / \sqrt{2}$, taking $A$ as positive real.The time-dependent wave function is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(x, t) &=e^{-i \hat{H} t / \hbar} \psi(x, 0) \\
&=\sum_{n}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)^{n+1} e^{-i \omega t\left(n+\frac{1}{2}\right)} \psi_{n}(x)
\end{aligned}
$$

The probability density is

$$
|\psi(x, t)|^{2}=\sum_{m n}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{\frac{m+n}{2}+1} e^{-i \omega t(n-m)} \psi_{n}(x) \psi_{m}^{*}(x)
$$

Note that the time factor $\exp [-i \omega(n-m) t]$ is a function with period $\frac{2 \pi}{(n-m) \omega}$, the maximum period being $2 \pi / \omega$.

The expectation value of energy is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{H} &=(\psi(x, 0), \hat{H} \psi(x, 0))=\sum_{m, n}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{\frac{m+n}{2}+1}\left(\psi_{n}, \hat{H} \psi_{m}\right) \\
&=\sum_{m, n}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{\frac{m+n}{2}+1}\left(m+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega \delta_{n m} \\
&=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2^{n+1}}\left(n+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega
\end{aligned}
$$

Noting

$$
\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{1}{x^{n}}=\frac{x}{x-1}
$$

or, by differentiation,

$$
\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{-n}{x^{n+1}}=\frac{-1}{(x-1)^{2}}
$$

we have

$$
\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{n}{2^{n+1}}=1
$$

and hence $\bar{H}=3 \hbar \omega / 2$.

Problem Statement:
A rigid body with moment of inertia of $I_{z}$ rotates freely in the $x-y$ plane. Let $\phi$ be the angle between the $x$-axis and the rotator axis.

At time $t=0$ the rotator is described by a wave packet $\psi(0)=$ $A \sin ^{2} \phi$. Find $\psi(t)$ for $t>0$.
Solution:
The Hamiltonian of a plane rotator is

$$
H=-\left(\hbar^{2} / 2 I_{z}\right) d^{2} / d \phi^{2}
$$

and so the Schrödinger equation is

$$
-\left(\hbar^{2} / 2 I_{z}\right) d^{2} \psi / d \phi^{2}=E \psi \text {. }
$$

Setting $\alpha^{2}=2 I_{z} E / \hbar^{2}$, we write the solution as

$$
\psi=A e^{i \alpha \phi}+B e^{-i \alpha \phi},
$$

where $A, B$ are arbitrary constants. For the wave function to be singlevalued, i.e. $\psi(\phi)=\psi(\phi+2 \pi)$, we require

$$
\alpha \equiv m=0, \quad \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots .
$$

The eigenvalues of energy are then

$$
E_{m}=m^{2} \hbar^{2} / 2 I_{z}, \quad m=0, \pm 1, \ldots
$$

and the corresponding eigenfunctions are

$$
\psi_{m}(\phi)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} e^{i m \phi}, \quad m=0, \pm 1, \ldots,
$$

after normalization $\int_{0}^{2 \pi} \psi_{m}^{*} \psi_{m} d \phi=1$At $t=0$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(0) &=A \sin ^{2} \phi=\frac{A}{2}(1-\cos 2 \phi) \\
&=A / 2-\frac{A}{4}\left(e^{i 2 \phi}+e^{-i 2 \phi}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which corresponds to $m=0$ and $m=\pm 2$. The angular speed is given by $E_{m}=\frac{1}{2} I_{z} \dot{\phi}^{2}$, or $\dot{\phi}=\frac{m \hbar}{I_{z}}$. Hence we have for time $t$ 

$$
\psi(t)=\frac{A}{2}-\frac{A}{4}\left[e^{i 2\left(\phi-\hbar t / I_{z}\right)}+e^{-i 2\left(\phi+\hbar t / I_{z}\right)}\right]
$$

Problem Statement:
Show that in the usual stationary state perturbation theory, if the Hamiltonian can be written $H=H_{0}+H^{\prime}$ with $H_{0} \phi_{0}=E_{0} \phi_{0}$, then the correction $\Delta E_{0}$ is

$$
\Delta E_{0} \approx\left\langle\phi_{0}\left|H^{\prime}\right| \phi_{0}\right\rangle .
$$

For a slightly deformed nucleus, it may be correspondingly assumed that the nucleons are in an elliptical well, again with infinite wall height, that is:

$$
V_{e l}= \begin{cases}0 & \text { inside the ellipsoid } \frac{x^{2}+y^{2}}{b^{2}}+\frac{z^{2}}{a^{2}}=1 \\ \infty & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}
$$

where $a \cong R(1+2 \beta / 3), b \cong R(1-\beta / 3)$, and $\beta \ll 1$.

Calculate the approximate change in the ground state energy $E_{0}$ due to the ellipticity of the non-spherical nucleus by finding an appropriate $H^{\prime}$ and using the result obtained in (a). HINT: Try to find a transformation of variables that will make the well look spherical.
Solution:
Assuming that $H^{\prime}$ is very small compared with $H_{0}$ so that the wave function $\Psi$ can be expanded as

$$
\Psi=\left|\phi_{0}\right\rangle+\lambda_{1}\left|\phi_{1}\right\rangle+\cdots+\lambda_{n}\left|\phi_{n}\right\rangle+\cdots,
$$

where $\lambda_{1} \cdots \lambda_{n} \cdots$ are small parameters. The Schrödinger equation is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left(H^{\prime}+H_{0}\right)\left(\left|\phi_{0}\right\rangle+\lambda_{1}\left|\phi_{1}\right\rangle+\cdots+\lambda_{n}\left|\phi_{n}\right\rangle+\cdots\right) \\
&\quad=\left(E_{0}+\Delta E_{0}\right)\left(\left|\phi_{0}\right\rangle+\lambda_{1}\left|\phi_{1}\right\rangle+\cdots+\lambda_{n}\left|\phi_{n}\right\rangle+\cdots\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Considering only the first order correction, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&H^{\prime}\left|\phi_{0}\right\rangle+H_{0}\left(\lambda_{1}\left|\phi_{1}\right\rangle+\cdots+\lambda_{n}\left|\phi_{n}\right\rangle+\cdots\right) \\
&\quad=\Delta E_{0}\left|\phi_{0}\right\rangle+E_{0}\left(\lambda_{1}\left|\phi_{1}\right\rangle+\cdots+\lambda_{n}\left|\phi_{n}\right\rangle+\cdots\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Multiplying both sides of the equation by $\left\langle\phi_{0}\right|$ and noting the orthonormality of the eigenfunctions we get 

$$
\Delta E_{0}=\left\langle\phi_{0}\left|H^{\prime}\right| \phi_{0}\right\rangle .
$$

Problem Statement:
The following theorem concerns the energy eigenvalues $E_{n}\left(E_{1}<E_{2}<\right.$ $E_{3}<\ldots$ ) of the Schrödinger equation in one dimension:

Theorem: If the potential $V_{1}(x)$ gives the eigenvalues $E_{1 n}$ and the potential $V_{2}(x)$ gives the eigenvalues $E_{2 n}$ and $V_{1}(x) \leq V_{2}(x)$ for all $x$, then $E_{1 n} \leq E_{2 n}$.

Now consider the potential (see figure)

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
U(x)=k x^{2} / 2, & |x|<a, \\
U(x)=k a^{2} / 2, & |x| \geq a .
\end{array}
$$

We want to determine the number of bound states that this potential can hold. Assume this number $N$ is $\gg 1$. It may be helpful to draw a qualitative picture of the wave function for the highest bound state.

For the potential 

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
V(x)=k a^{2} / 2, & |x|>a, \\
V(x)=0, & |x| \leq a .
\end{array}
$$

use the theorem above to determine either a rigorous upper and lower bound to $N$.
(Both can be done but you are asked for only one.)
Solution:
Define $V(\lambda, x)=\lambda V_{2}(x)+(1-\lambda) V_{1}(x)$. Obviously $V(0, x)=$ $V_{1}(x), V(1, x)=V_{2}(x), \partial V / \partial \lambda=V_{2}(x)-V_{1}(x) \geq 0$. The Hamiltonian is then

$$
\hat{H}(\lambda)=\hat{p}^{2} / 2 m+V(\lambda, x),
$$

and the eigenequation is

$$
\hat{H}(\lambda)|n, \lambda\rangle=E_{n}(\lambda)|n, \lambda\rangle
$$

where $E_{n}(\lambda)=\langle n, \lambda|\hat{H}(\lambda)| n, \lambda\rangle$. As 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\partial E_{n}(\lambda) / \partial \lambda &=\frac{\partial}{\partial \lambda}[\langle n, \lambda|\hat{H}(\lambda)| n, \lambda\rangle] \\
&=\langle n \lambda|\partial V(\lambda) / \partial \lambda| n \lambda\rangle \\
&=\int \frac{\partial V}{\partial \lambda}\left|\psi_{n}(x, \lambda)\right|^{2} d x \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

we have $E_{1 n}=E_{n}(0) \leq E_{n}(1)=E_{2 n}$, and the theorem is proved. Note that we have used $\langle n \lambda \mid n \lambda\rangle=1$.Let $V(x)=k x^{2} / 2$. Then $V(x) \geq U(x)$. If $E_{n}$ is an energy level for the potential $U(x)$, then $E_{n} \leq(n+1 / 2) \hbar \omega$, where $\omega=\sqrt{k / m}$. For a bound state, $E_{n} \leq k a^{2} / 2$. Solving $(N+1 / 2) \hbar \omega \leq k a^{2} / 2$, we find

$$
N \leq \frac{m \omega a^{2}}{2 \hbar}-\frac{1}{2}=\left[\frac{m \omega a^{2}}{2 \hbar}\right]
$$

where $[A]$ indicates the maximum integer that is less than $A$.

We now choose for $V(x)$ a square well of finite depth,

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
V(x)=k a^{2} / 2, & |x|>a, \\
V(x)=0, & |x| \leq a .
\end{array}
$$

The number of bound states of $U(x)$ is less than that of $V(x)$, which for the latter is $\left[2 m \omega a^{2} / \pi \hbar\right]+1$. We can take the upper bound to the number of bound states of $U(x)$ as $\left[2 m \omega a^{2} / \pi \hbar\right]$ as for $N \gg 1$ the term 1 can be neglected. Taken together, we get that the number of bound states is between $\left[m \omega a^{2} / 2 \hbar\right]$ and $\left[2 m \omega a^{2} / \pi \hbar\right]$.

Problem Statement: A quantum mechanical rigid rotor constrained to rotate in one plane has moment of inertia I about its axis of rotation and electric dipole moment $\boldsymbol{\mu}$ (in the plane). This rotor is placed in a weak uniform electric field $\varepsilon$, which is in the plane of rotation. Treating the electric field as a perturbation, find the first non-vanishing corrections to the energy levels of the rotor.
Solution:
Take the plane of rotation of the rotor as the $x y$ plane with the $x$-axis parallel to $\varepsilon$ as shown in Fig. 5.9. In the absence of external electric field the Hamiltonian of rotor is

$$
H_{0}=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 I} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \theta^{2}},
$$

and the eigenequation is

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 I} \frac{\partial^{2} \psi}{\partial \theta^{2}}=E \psi,
$$

which has solutions

$$
\psi=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} e^{i m \theta}, \quad m=0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots
$$

corresponding to energy levels

$$
E_{m}^{(0)}=\frac{\hbar^{2} m^{2}}{2 I} .
$$

When the external electric field acts on the system and may be treated as perturbation, the Hamiltonian of perturbation is

$$
H^{\prime}=-\mu \cdot \varepsilon=-\mu \varepsilon \cos \theta .
$$

The first order energy correction is

$$
E^{(1)}=\left\langle m\left|H^{\prime}\right| m\right\rangle=-\frac{\mu \varepsilon}{2 \pi} \int_{0}^{2 \pi} \cos \theta d \theta=0
$$

The second order energy correction is

$$
E^{(2)}=\sum_{m^{\prime} \neq m}^{\prime} \frac{\left|\left\langle m^{\prime}\left|H^{\prime}\right| m\right\rangle\right|^{2}}{E_{m}^{(0)}-E_{m^{\prime}}^{(0)}} .
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle m^{\prime}\left|H^{\prime}\right| m\right\rangle &=-\frac{\mu \varepsilon}{2 \pi} \int_{0}^{2 \pi} e^{i\left(m-m^{\prime}\right) \theta} \cos \theta d \theta \\
&=-\frac{\mu \varepsilon}{4 \pi} \int_{0}^{2 \pi}\left[e^{i\left(m-m^{\prime}+1\right) \theta}+e^{i\left(m-m^{\prime}-1\right) \theta}\right] d \theta \\
&=-\frac{\mu \varepsilon}{2}\left(\delta_{m^{\prime}, m+1}+\delta_{m^{\prime}, m-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
E^{(2)} &=\frac{\mu^{2} \varepsilon^{2}}{4} \cdot \frac{2 I}{\hbar^{2}}\left[\frac{1}{m^{2}-(m-1)^{2}}+\frac{1}{m^{2}-(m+1)^{2}}\right] \\
&=\frac{\mu^{2} \varepsilon^{2} I}{\hbar^{2}} \cdot \frac{1}{4 m^{2}-1} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Problem Statement:
Suppose an atom is initially in an excited ${ }^{1} S_{0}$ state (first figure) and subsequently decays into a lower, short-lived ${ }^{1} P_{1}$ state with emission of a photon $\gamma_{1}$ (second figure). Soon after, it decays into the ${ }^{1} S_{0}$ ground state by emitting a second photon $\gamma_{2}$ (third figure). Let $\theta$ be the angle between the two emitted photons.

What is the ratio of finding both photons with the same circular polarization to that of finding the photons with opposite circular polarizations?

It may be of some help to know the rotation matrices $d_{m^{\prime} m}$, which relate one angular momentum representation in one coordinate system to another angular momentum representation in a rotated coordinate system, given below:

$$
\begin{array}{cccc}
m=1 & m=0 & m=-1 \\
m^{\prime}=1
\end{array}\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\frac{1+\cos \alpha}{2} & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \alpha & \frac{1-\cos \alpha}{2} \\
\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \alpha & \cos \alpha & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \alpha \\
\frac{1-\cos \alpha}{2} & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \alpha & \frac{1+\cos \alpha}{2}
\end{array}\right)
$$

where $\alpha$ is the angle between the $z$-axis of one system and the $z^{\prime}$-axis of the other.
Solution:
The atom is initially in the excited state ${ }^{1} S_{0}$. Thus the projection of the atomic angular momentum on an arbitrary $z$ direction is $L_{z}=0$. We can take the direction of the first photon emission as the $z$ direction. After the emission of the photon and the atom goes into the ${ }^{1} P_{1}$ state, if the angular momentum of that photon is $L_{z}=\pm \hbar$, correspondingly the angular momentum of the atomic state ${ }^{1} P_{1}$ is $L_{z}=\mp \hbar$, i.e., $m_{z}=\mp 1$. If we let the direction of emission of the second photon be the $z^{\prime}$-axis the projection of the eigenstate of the $z$-component of angular momentum on the $z^{\prime}$ direction is equivalent to multiplying the initial state with the $d_{m^{\prime} m}$ matrix. Only atoms that are in states $m_{z}^{\prime}=\pm 1$ can emit photon (as $L_{z}^{\prime}=\pm \hbar$ must be satisfied) in $z^{\prime}$ direction and make the atom decay into the ${ }^{1} S_{0}$ state $\left(m_{z}^{\prime}=0\right)$. Then the transitions are from $m=\pm 1$ to $m^{\prime}=\pm 1$, and we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& C_{1}=\left\langle m_{z^{\prime}}=-1\left|d_{m^{\prime} m}\right| m_{z}=+1\right\rangle \\
& =(0,0,1)\left(\begin{array}{ccc}\frac{1+\cos \theta}{2} & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta & \frac{1-\cos \theta}{2} \\\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta & \cos \theta & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta \\\frac{1-\cos \theta}{2} & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta & \frac{1+\cos \theta}{2}\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\0 \\0\end{array}\right) \\
& =\frac{1-\cos \theta}{2}, \\
& C_{2}=\left\langle m_{z^{\prime}}=+1\left|d_{m^{\prime} m}\right| m_{z}=+1\right\rangle \\
& =(1,0,0)\left(\begin{array}{ccc}\frac{1+\cos \theta}{2} & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta & \frac{1-\cos \theta}{2} \\\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta & \cos \theta & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta \\\frac{1-\cos \theta}{2} & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta & \frac{1+\cos \theta}{2}\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\0 \\0\end{array}\right) \\
& =\frac{1+\cos \theta}{2}, \\
& C_{3}=\left\langle m_{z^{\prime}}=+1\left|d_{m^{\prime} m}\right| m_{z}=-1\right\rangle=\frac{1-\cos \theta}{2}, \\
& C_{4}=\left\langle m_{z^{\prime}}=-1\left|d_{m^{\prime} m}\right| m_{z}=-1\right\rangle=\frac{1+\cos \theta}{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The relative probability of $\theta$ is

$$
P(\theta) \propto\left|C_{1}\right|^{2}+\left|C_{2}\right|^{2}+\left|C_{3}\right|^{2}+\left|C_{4}\right|^{2}=1+\cos ^{2} \theta .
$$The ratio of the probability of finding both photons with the same circular polarization to that of finding the photons with opposite circular polarizations is

$$
\left(\left|C_{2}\right|^{2}+\left|C_{4}\right|^{2}\right) /\left(\left|C_{1}\right|^{2}+\left|C_{3}\right|^{2}\right)=(1+\cos \theta)^{2} /(1-\cos \theta)^{2} .
$$

Problem Statement:
A mass $m$ is attached by a massless rod of length $l$ to a pivot $P$ and swings in a vertical plane under the influence of gravity (see the figure).

Find the lowest order correction to the ground state energy resulting from inaccuracy of the small angle approximation.
Solution:
Take the equilibrium position of the point mass as the zero point of potential energy. For small angle approximation, the potential energy of the system is

$$
V=m g l(1-\cos \theta) \approx \frac{1}{2} m g l \theta^{2}

and the Hamiltonian is 

$$
H=\frac{1}{2} m l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m g l \theta^{2} .

$$
E_{n}=\left(n+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
H^{\prime} &=m g l(1-\cos \theta)-\frac{1}{2} m g l \theta^{2} \\
& \approx-\frac{1}{24} m g l \theta^{4}=-\frac{1}{24} \frac{m g}{l^{3}} x^{4},
\end{aligned}

A particle of charge $q$ moving in one dimension is initially bound to a delta function potential at the origin. From time $t=0$ to $t=\tau$ it is exposed to a constant electric field $\varepsilon_{0}$ in the $x$ direction as shown in the figure. The object of this problem is to find the probability that for $t>\tau$ the particle will be found in an unbound state with energy between $E_{k}$ and $E_{k}+d E_{k}$.

Assume that the electric field may be treated as a perturbation. Find the matrix element of the perturbation term $\hat{H}_{1}$ between the initial state and the final state, $\left\langle 0\left|\hat{H}_{1}\right| k\right\rangle$.
Solution:
The energy eigenfunction satisfies the Schrödinger equation

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2} \psi}{d x^{2}}-A \delta(\mathbf{x}) \psi=E \psi,
$$

where $E<0$, or

$$
\frac{d^{2} \psi}{d x^{2}}-k^{2} \psi+A_{0} \delta(\mathbf{x}) \psi=0
$$

with

$$
k=\sqrt{\frac{2 m|E|}{\hbar^{2}}}, \quad A_{0}=\frac{2 m A}{\hbar^{2}} .
$$

Integrating this equation from $-\varepsilon$ to $+\varepsilon, \varepsilon$ being an arbitrary small positive number and then letting $\varepsilon \rightarrow 0$, we get

$$
\psi^{\prime}(+0)-\psi^{\prime}(-0)=-A_{0} \psi(0) .
$$

We also have from the continuity of the wave function at $x=0$

$$
\psi(+0)=\psi(-0)=\psi(0) .
$$

Thus

$$
\frac{\psi^{\prime}(+0)}{\psi(+0)}-\frac{\psi^{\prime}(-0)}{\psi(-0)}=-A_{0} .
$$

Solving the Schrödinger equation for $x \neq 0$ we get $\psi(x)=C e^{-k|x|}$. Then as $\psi(x)=C e^{-k x}$ for $x>0$ and $\psi(x)=C e^{k x}$ for $x<0$ we have

$$
\frac{\psi^{\prime}(+0)}{\psi(+0)}-\frac{\psi^{\prime}(-0)}{\psi(-0)}=-2 k .
$$

Hence

$$
k=\frac{A_{0}}{2}=\frac{m A}{\hbar^{2}} .
$$

The energy level for the bound state is

$$
E=-\frac{\hbar^{2} k^{2}}{2 m}=-\frac{m A^{2}}{2 \hbar^{2}}
$$

and the corresponding normalized eigenfunction is

$$
\psi(\mathbf{x})=\sqrt{\frac{m A}{\hbar^{2}}} \exp \left(-\frac{m A}{\hbar^{2}}|x|\right)
$$If the unbound states can be approximately represented by a plane wave $e^{i k x}$ in a one-dimensional box of length $L$ with periodic boundary conditions, we have

$$
\exp \left[i k\left(-\frac{L}{2}\right)\right]=\exp \left(i k \frac{L}{2}\right)
$$

which gives $e^{i k L}=1$, or

$$
k L=2 n \pi . \quad(n=0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots)
$$

Hence

$$
k=\frac{2 n \pi}{L}=k_{n}, \quad \text { say. }
$$

Thus the normalized plane wave function for wave vector $k$ is

$$
\psi_{k}(\mathbf{x})=\frac{1}{\sqrt{L}} e^{i k x}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{L}} \exp \left[i\left(\frac{2 n \pi}{L} x\right)\right]
$$

Note that the state of energy $E_{k}$ is two-fold degenerate when $k \neq 0$, so the number of states with momenta between $p$ and $p+d p$ is

$$
\frac{L d p}{2 \pi \hbar}=D(k) d k=\frac{1}{2} D\left(E_{k}\right) d E_{k}
$$

As $k, p$ and $E_{k}$ are related by

$$
k=\frac{p}{\hbar}, E_{k}=\frac{p^{2}}{2 m}=\frac{\hbar^{2} k^{2}}{2 m},
$$

we have

$$
D(k)=\frac{L}{2 \pi}, \quad D\left(E_{k}\right)=\frac{L}{\pi \hbar} \sqrt{\frac{m}{2 E_{k}}} .
$$Treating $\varepsilon_{0}$ as a perturbation, the perturbation Hamiltonian is $\hat{H}_{1}=$ $-q \varepsilon_{0} x$. Its matrix element between the initial and final states is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle k\left|\hat{H}_{1}\right| 0\right\rangle=& \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \psi_{k}^{*}\left(-q \varepsilon_{0} x\right) \psi d x \\
=&-\frac{q \varepsilon_{0}}{\sqrt{L}} \sqrt{\frac{m A}{\hbar^{2}}} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} x \exp \left(-i k x-k_{0}|x|\right) d x \\
=&-\frac{q \varepsilon_{0}}{\sqrt{L}} \sqrt{\frac{m A}{\hbar^{2}}} i \frac{d}{d k} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \exp \left(-i k x-k_{0}|x|\right) d x \\
=&-\frac{q \varepsilon_{0}}{\sqrt{L}} \sqrt{\frac{m A}{\hbar^{2}}} i \frac{d}{d k}\left[\int_{-\infty}^{0} \exp \left(-i k x+k_{0} x\right) d x\right.\\
&\left.+\int_{0}^{\infty} \exp \left(-i k x-k_{0} x\right) d x\right] \\
=&-\frac{q \varepsilon_{0}}{\sqrt{L}} \sqrt{\frac{m A}{\hbar^{2}}}\left(-4 i k k_{0}\right) \frac{1}{\left[k^{2}+k_{0}^{2}\right]^{2}} \\
=& \frac{4 i q \varepsilon_{0}}{\sqrt{L}}\left(\frac{m A}{\hbar^{2}}\right)^{3 / 2} \frac{k}{\left[k^{2}+\left(\frac{m A}{\hbar^{2}}\right)^{2}\right]^{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Problem Statement:
Consider the one-dimensional motion of an electron confined to a potential well $V(x)=\frac{1}{2} k x^{2}$ and subjected also to a perturbing electric field $\mathbf{F}=F \hat{\mathbf{x}}$

The dipole moment of this system in state $n$ is defined as $P_{n}=$ $-e\langle x\rangle_{n}$, where $\langle x\rangle_{n}$ is the expectation value of $x$ in the state $n$. Find the dipole moment of the system in the presence of the electric field.
Solution:
The Hamiltonian of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
H &=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \nabla^{2}+\frac{1}{2} k x^{2}-q F x \\
&=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \nabla^{2}+\frac{1}{2} k\left(x-\frac{q F}{k}\right)^{2}-\frac{q^{2} F^{2}}{2 k} \\
&=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \nabla^{\prime 2}+\frac{1}{2} k x^{\prime 2}-\frac{q^{2} F^{2}}{2 k}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $x^{\prime}=x-\frac{q F}{k}$. Hence the energy shift due to the perturbing electric field $F \hat{\mathbf{x}}$ is

$$
E^{\prime}=\frac{q^{2} F^{2}}{2 k}=\frac{e^{2} F^{2}}{2 k} .
$$The expectation value of $x$ in state $n$ is

$$
\langle x\rangle_{n}=\left\langle x^{\prime}+\frac{q F}{k}\right\rangle=\left\langle x^{\prime}\right\rangle+\left\langle\frac{q F}{k}\right\rangle=\frac{q F}{k} .
$$

Therefore the dipole moment of the system is

$$
P_{n}=-e \frac{q F}{k}=e^{2} \frac{F}{k},(q=-e) .
$$

Problem Statement:
It can be shown that the probability for an on-shell charged particle with initial momentum $P$ to emit a virtual photon with momentum $q$ is proportional to the covariant tensor

$$
W_{\mu \nu}=A g_{\mu \nu}+B P_{\mu} P_{\nu}+C q_{\mu} q_{\nu}+D\left(q_{\mu} P_{\nu}+P_{\mu} q_{\nu}\right)
$$

where $A, B, C$ and $D$ are real Lorentz-invariant scalar functions of $q^{2}, q \cdot P$ and $P^{2}=m^{2}$.

Compute $W_{1}$ for a Dirac particle of mass $m$ for which

$$
W_{\mu \nu}=\operatorname{Tr}\left[(P-\not q+m) \gamma_{\mu}(\mathbb{P}+m) \gamma_{\nu}\right] .
$$
Solution:
Current conservation requires $q^{\mu} W_{\mu \nu}=0$, i.e.,

$$
A q_{\nu}+B(q \cdot P) P_{\nu}+C q^{2} q_{\nu}+D\left[q^{2} P_{\nu}+(q \cdot P) q_{\nu}\right]=0
$$

where $q \cdot P=q^{\mu} P_{\mu}, q_{\nu}=q^{\mu} g_{\mu \nu}$, etc. As $P_{\nu}, q_{\nu}$ are independent and $q^{2} \neq 0$, this gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
A+C q^{2}+D(q \cdot P) &=0 \\
B(q \cdot P)+D q^{2} &=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Solving for $\mathrm{C}$ and $\mathrm{D}$ and writing $A=W_{1}, B=W_{2}$, we have

$$
D=-W_{2} \frac{(q \cdot P)}{q^{2}}, \quad C=-\frac{W_{1}}{q^{2}}+\frac{W_{2}(q \cdot P)^{2}}{q^{4}} .
$$

Hence

$$
W_{\mu \nu}=W_{1}\left(g_{\mu \nu}-\frac{q_{\mu} q_{\nu}}{q^{2}}\right)+W_{2}\left(P_{\mu}-q_{\mu} \frac{q \cdot P}{q^{2}}\right) \cdot\left(P_{\nu}-q_{\nu} \frac{q \cdot P}{q^{2}}\right) .
$$

We are given

$$
\begin{aligned}
W_{\mu \nu}=& \operatorname{Tr}\left[(\mathbb{P}-\not q+m) \gamma_{\mu}(\mathbb{P}+m) \gamma_{\nu}\right] \\
=& \operatorname{Tr}\left[\boldsymbol{P} \gamma_{\mu} \boldsymbol{P} \gamma_{\nu}+\boldsymbol{P} \gamma_{\mu} m \gamma_{\nu}-\not q \gamma_{\mu} \boldsymbol{P} \gamma_{\nu}\right.\\
&\left.-\not q \gamma_{\mu} m \gamma_{\nu}+m \gamma_{\mu} \boldsymbol{P} \gamma_{\nu}+m \gamma_{\mu} m \gamma_{\nu}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where $P=P_{\alpha} \gamma^{\alpha}, \not q=q_{\alpha} \gamma^{\alpha}$. The Dirac matrices satisfy the anticommutation relation

$$
\left\{\gamma^{\mu}, \gamma^{\nu}\right\} \equiv \gamma^{\mu} \gamma^{\nu}+\gamma^{\nu} \gamma^{\mu}=2 g^{\mu \nu}
$$

and so

$$
\operatorname{Tr}\left(\gamma^{\mu} \gamma^{\nu}\right)=4 g^{\mu \nu}
$$

$$
\begin{gathered}
\operatorname{Tr}\left(\gamma^{\mu_{1}} \gamma^{\mu_{2}} \cdots \gamma^{\mu_{n}}\right)=0 \text { for } n=\text { odd } \\
\operatorname{Tr}\left(\gamma^{\mu} \gamma^{\nu} \gamma^{\lambda} \gamma^{\sigma}\right)=4\left(g^{\mu \nu} g^{\lambda \sigma}-g^{\mu \lambda} g^{\nu \sigma}+g^{\mu \sigma} g^{\nu \lambda}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

Hence in $W_{\mu \nu}$ the terms involving an odd number of $\gamma$ vanish. Consider

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Tr}\left(\mathbb{P} \gamma_{\mu} P \gamma_{\nu}\right) &=\operatorname{Tr}\left(P_{\alpha} \gamma^{\alpha} g_{\mu \lambda} \gamma^{\lambda} P_{\beta} \gamma^{\beta} g_{\nu \sigma} \gamma^{\sigma}\right) \\
&=P_{\alpha} g_{\mu \lambda} P_{\beta} g_{\nu \sigma} \operatorname{Tr}\left(\gamma^{\alpha} \gamma^{\lambda} \gamma^{\beta} \gamma^{\sigma}\right) \\
&=4 P_{\alpha} g_{\mu \lambda} P_{\beta} g_{\nu \sigma}\left(g^{\alpha \lambda} g^{\beta \sigma}-g^{\alpha \beta} g^{\lambda \sigma}+g^{\alpha \sigma} g^{\lambda \beta}\right) \\
&=4\left(P_{\alpha} \delta_{\mu}^{\alpha} P_{\beta} \delta_{\nu}^{\beta}-P^{\beta} P_{\beta} \delta_{\mu}^{\sigma} g_{\nu \sigma}+P_{\alpha} g_{\nu}^{\alpha} P_{\beta} \delta_{\mu}^{\beta}\right) \\
&=4\left(P_{\mu} P_{\nu}-P^{2} g_{\mu \nu}+P_{\nu} P_{\mu}\right) \\
\operatorname{Tr}\left(q \gamma_{\mu} P \gamma_{\nu}\right) &=4\left(h_{\mu} P_{\nu}-\mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{P} g_{\mu \nu}+g_{\nu} P_{\mu}\right) \\
\operatorname{Tr}\left(m^{2} \gamma_{\mu} \gamma_{\nu}\right) &=m^{2} g_{\mu \alpha} g_{\nu \beta} \operatorname{Tr}\left(\gamma^{\alpha} \gamma^{\beta}\right) \\
&=4 m^{2} g_{\mu \alpha} g_{\nu \beta} g^{\alpha \beta}=4 m^{2} g_{\mu \alpha} \delta_{\nu}^{\alpha}=4 m^{2} g_{\mu \nu}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then, as for an on-shell particle $P^{2} \approx m^{2}$, we have

$$
W_{\mu \nu}=4 \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{P} g_{\mu \nu}+8 P_{\mu} P_{\nu}-4\left(q_{\mu} P_{\nu}+q_{\nu} P_{\mu}\right)
$$

A comparison with the given expression for $W \mu \nu$ we find

$$
W_{1}=4 \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{P}, \quad W_{2}=8 .
$$

Note that for an on-shell charge emitting a virtual photon, initially $P^{2}=$ $m^{2}$, and finally $(\mathbf{P}-\mathbf{q})^{2}=P^{2}-2 \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{P}+q^{2}=m^{2}$, and so the two expressions for $W_{\mu \nu}$ are consistent.

Problem Statement:
An $\Omega^{-}$hyperon (spin $3 / 2$, mass $1672 \mathrm{MeV} / \mathrm{c}^{2}$, intrinsic parity $+$ ) can decay via the weak interaction into a $\Lambda$ hyperon (spin $1 / 2$, mass $1116 \mathrm{MeV} / \mathrm{c}^{2}$, intrinsic parity $+$ ) and a $K^{-}$meson (spin 0 , mass $494 \mathrm{MeV} / \mathrm{c}^{2}$, intrinsic parity $-)$, i.e., $\Omega^{-} \rightarrow \Lambda+K^{-}$.

What is the most general form of the angular distribution of the $K^{-}$mesons relative to the spin direction of the $\Omega^{-}$for the case when the $\Omega^{-}$has a maximum possible component of angular momentum along the $z$-axis, i.e., the initial state $\left|\Omega_{j}^{m}\right\rangle=\left|\Omega_{3 / 2}^{+3 / 2}\right\rangle$.

(Berkeley)
Solution:
The initial state of the system is $|3 / 2,3 / 2\rangle$, where the values are the orbital and spin momenta of the $\Omega^{-}$. The spin part of the final state is $\left|1 / 2, s_{z}\right\rangle|0,0\rangle=\left|1 / 2, s_{z}\right\rangle$, and the orbital part is $Y_{l m}(\theta, \varphi)=|l, m\rangle$. Thus the total final state of this system is

$$
|l, m\rangle\left|1 / 2, s_{z}\right\rangle \text {. }
$$

By conservation of angular momentum $l=1,2 ; m=3 / 2-s_{z}$. Thus the final state is a $p$ wave if $l=1$, the state being $|1,1\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle$; a $d$ wave if $l=2$, the state being a combination of $|2,2\rangle|1 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle$ and $|2,1\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle$

Hence the wave functions are

$$
\psi_{p}=Y_{11}(\theta, \varphi)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi_{d} &=\left[\sqrt{\frac{4}{5}}|2,2\rangle\left|\frac{1}{2},-\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle-\sqrt{\frac{1}{5}}|2,1\rangle\left|\frac{1}{2},-\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle\right] \\
&=\left(\begin{array}{c}
-\sqrt{\frac{1}{5}} Y_{21}(\theta, \varphi) \\
\sqrt{\frac{4}{5}} Y_{22}(\theta, \varphi)
\end{array}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi &=a_{d} \psi_{d}+a_{p} \psi_{p} \\
&=\left(\begin{array}{c}
a_{p} Y_{11}(\theta, \varphi)-a_{d} \sqrt{\frac{1}{5}} Y_{21}(\theta, \varphi) \\
\sqrt{\frac{4}{5}} a_{d} Y_{22}(\theta, \varphi)
\end{array}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore

$$
\psi^{*} \psi=\frac{3}{8 \pi} \sin ^{2} \theta\left[\left|a_{p}\right|^{2}+\left|a_{d}\right|^{2}-2 R e a_{p}^{*} a_{d} \cos \theta\right],
$$

i.e., the intensity of the emitted particles is

$$
I \propto \sin ^{2} \theta(1+\alpha \cos \theta),
$$

where

$$
\alpha=-2 \operatorname{Re} a_{p}^{*} a_{d} /\left(\left|a_{p}\right|^{2}+\left|a_{d}\right|^{2}\right) .
$$

This is the most general form of the angular distribution of the $\mathrm{K}^{-}$mesons.

Problem Statement: A one-dimensional box of width $L$ contains two spinless particles each of mass $m$. The interaction between the particles is described by a potential energy $V\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)=a \delta\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)$. Calculate the ground state energy to first order in $a$.
Solution:
Neglecting the $\delta$-potential, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&V\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)= \begin{cases}0, & 0 \leq x_{1}, x_{2} \leq L \\
\infty, & \text { otherwise }\end{cases} \\
&H_{0}=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x_{1}^{2}}-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x_{2}^{2}}+V\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the results for an infinitely deep potential well, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\psi_{n l}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)=\psi_{n}\left(x_{1}\right) \psi_{l}\left(x_{2}\right) \\
&=\frac{2}{L} \sin \left(\frac{n \pi}{L} x_{1}\right) \sin \left(\frac{l \pi}{L} x_{2}\right), \\
&E_{n l}=\frac{\hbar^{2} \pi^{2}}{2 m L^{2}}\left(n^{2}+l^{2}\right), \quad n, l=1,2, \cdots .
\end{aligned}
$$

For the ground state, $n=l=1$,

$$
E_{11}=\hbar^{2} \pi^{2} / m L^{2} .
$$

Now consider the $\delta$-potential as a perturbation

$$
\hat{H}^{\prime}=a \delta\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right) .
$$

The correction to the ground state energy due to the perturbation is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{H}^{\prime} &=\langle 11|\hat{H}| 11\rangle \\
&=\int_{0}^{L} \int_{0}^{L} a \delta\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right) \sin ^{2}\left(\frac{\pi}{L} x_{1}\right) \sin ^{2}\left(\frac{\pi}{L} x_{2}\right)\left(\frac{2}{L}\right)^{2} d x_{1} d x_{2} \\
&=a\left(\frac{2}{L}\right)^{2} \int_{0}^{L} \sin ^{4}\left(\frac{\pi}{L} x_{1}\right) d x_{1}=\frac{3 a}{2 L},
\end{aligned}
$$

and the ground state energy is

$$
E_{11}^{\prime}=E_{11}+\bar{H}^{\prime}=\frac{\pi^{2} \hbar^{2}}{m L^{2}}+\frac{3 a}{2 L} .
$$

Problem Statement:
A particle of mass $m$ is scattered by the central potential

$$
V(r)=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{m a^{2}} \frac{1}{\cosh ^{2}(r / a)}
$$

where $a$ is a constant. Given that the equation

$$
\frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}+k^{2} y+\frac{2}{\cosh ^{2} x} y=0
$$

has the solutions $y=e^{\pm i k x}(\tanh x \mp i k)$, calculate the $s$-wave contribution to the total scattering cross section at energy $E$.
Solution:
Letting $\chi_{0}(r)=r R(r)$ we have for the radial part of the Schrödinger equation for $s$-waves $(\ell=0)$

$$
\frac{d^{2} \chi_{0}(r)}{d r^{2}}+\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}}\left[E+\frac{\hbar^{2}}{m a^{2}} \frac{1}{\cosh ^{2}(r / a)}\right] \chi_{0}(r)=0 .
$$

With $x=r / a, y(x)=\chi_{0}(r)$ and $k=\sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}}$, the above becomes

$$
\frac{d^{2} y(x)}{d x^{2}}+k^{2} a^{2} y(x)+\frac{2}{\cosh ^{2}(x)} y(x)=0 .
$$

This equation has solutions $y=e^{\pm i a k x}(\tanh x \mp i a k)$. For $R$ finite at $r=0$ we require $y(0)=0$. The solution that satisfies this condition has the form

$$
\begin{aligned}
y(x) &=e^{i a k x}(\tanh x-i a k)+e^{-i a k x}(\tanh x+i a k) \\
&=2 \cos (a k x) \tanh x+2 a k \sin (a k x)
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
\chi_{0}(r)=2 \cos (k r) \tanh \left(\frac{r}{a}\right)+2 a k \sin (k r) .
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{1}{\chi_{0}} \frac{d \chi_{0}}{d r}=\frac{a k^{2} \cos (k r)-k \sin (k r) \tanh \left(\frac{r}{a}\right)+\frac{1}{a} \cos (k r) \operatorname{sech}^{2}\left(\frac{r}{a}\right)}{a k \sin (k r)+\cos (k r) \tanh \left(\frac{r}{a}\right)} \\
\stackrel{r \rightarrow \infty}{\longrightarrow} \frac{a k^{2} \cos (k r)-k \sin (k r)}{a k \sin (k r)+\cos (k r)}=k \frac{a k \cot (k r)-1}{\cot (k r)+a k} .
\end{gathered}
$$

On the other hand if we write $\chi_{0}$ in the form

$$
\chi_{0}(r)=\sin \left(k r+\delta_{0}\right),
$$

then as

$$
\frac{1}{\chi_{0}} \frac{d \chi_{0}}{d r}=k \cot \left(k r+\delta_{0}\right)=k \frac{\cot (k r) \cot \delta_{0}-1}{\cot (k r)+\cot \delta_{0}},
$$

we have to put

$$
\cot \delta_{0}=a k,
$$

or

$$
\sin ^{2} \delta_{0}=\frac{1}{1+a^{2} k^{2}} .
$$

Hence the $s$-wave contribution to the total scattering cross section is

$$
\sigma_{t}=\frac{4 \pi}{k^{2}} \sin ^{2} \delta_{0}=\frac{4 \pi}{k^{2}} \frac{1}{1+a^{2} k^{2}}=\frac{2 \pi \hbar^{2}}{m E} \frac{1}{1+\frac{2 a^{2} m E}{\hbar^{2}}}
$$

Problem Statement: The spin functions for a free electron in a basis where $\hat{s}_{z}$ is diagonal can be written as $\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0\end{array}\right)$ and $\left(\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 1\end{array}\right)$ with eigenvalues of $\hat{s}_{z}$ being $+1 / 2$ and $-1 / 2$ respectively. Using this basis find a normalized eigenfunction of $\hat{s}_{y}$ with eigenvalue $-1 / 2$
Solution:
In the diagonal representation of $\hat{s}^{2}, \hat{s}_{z}$, we can represent $\hat{s}_{y}$ by

$$
\hat{s}_{y}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{rr}
0 & -i \\
i & 0
\end{array}\right), \quad(\hbar=1) .
$$

Let the required eigenfunction of $\hat{s}_{y}$ be $\sigma_{y}=\left(\begin{array}{l}a \\ b\end{array}\right)$. Then as

$$
\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{rr}
0 & -i \\
i & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right)=-\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right),
$$

we have $a=i b$, and so $\sigma_{y}=b\left(\begin{array}{l}i \\ 1\end{array}\right)$

Normalization

$$
\sigma_{y}^{+} \sigma_{y}=b^{2}(-i, 1)\left(\begin{array}{c}
i \\
1
\end{array}\right)=2 b^{2}=1
$$

gives $b=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$. Hence

$$
\sigma_{y}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
i \\
1
\end{array}\right)
$$

Solution:
The unperturbed Hamiltonian of the system is

$$
H_{0}=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m}\left(\nabla_{2}^{1}+\nabla_{2}^{2}\right)-\frac{Z e^{2}}{r_{1}}-\frac{Z e^{2}}{r_{2}} .
$$

The wave functions have the form

$$
\Phi=\phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right) \chi_{0}\left(s_{1 z}, s_{2 z}\right)
$$

For the ground state,

$$
\phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right)=\psi_{100}\left(r_{1}\right) \psi_{100}\left(r_{2}\right)
$$

where

$$
\psi_{100}(r)=\sqrt{\frac{Z^{3}}{\pi a_{0}^{3}}} \exp \left\{-Z r / a_{0}\right\}
$$

with $a_{0}=\hbar^{2} / m e^{2}$. Treating the electron-electron interaction $\frac{e^{2}}{\left|\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}\right|}$ as a perturbation, the energy correction to first order in perturbation theory is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta E=\left\langle H^{\prime}\right\rangle &=e^{2} \iint \frac{d^{3} \mathbf{r}_{1} d^{3} \mathbf{r}_{2}}{\left|\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}\right|}\left|\psi_{100}\left(r_{1}\right)\right|^{2}\left|\psi_{100}\left(r_{2}\right)\right|^{2} \\
&=e^{2}\left(\frac{Z^{3}}{\pi a_{0}^{3}}\right)^{2} \iint \frac{d^{3} \mathbf{r}_{1} d^{3} \mathbf{r}_{2}}{\left|\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}\right|} \exp \left[-\frac{2 Z}{a_{0}}\left(r_{1}+r_{2}\right)\right] \\
&=e^{2}\left(\frac{Z^{3}}{\pi a_{0}^{3}}\right)^{2} \cdot \frac{20 \pi^{2}}{\left(\frac{2 Z}{a_{0}}\right)^{5}}=\frac{5 Z e^{2}}{8 a_{0}}
\end{aligned}
$$

The energy levels of a hydrogen-like atom are given by

$$
E_{n}=-\frac{e^{2}}{2 a_{0}} \frac{Z^{2}}{n^{2}} .
$$

and so the energy of the ground state of the system excluding the electronelectron Coulomb interaction is

$$
E_{0}=-2 \frac{e^{2} Z^{2}}{2 a_{0}}=-\frac{e^{2} Z^{2}}{a_{0}} .
$$

Hence the corrected energy of the ground state of helium is

$$
E=-\frac{e^{2} Z^{2}}{a_{0}}+\frac{5 Z e^{2}}{8 a_{0}}=-\frac{11 e^{2}}{4 \alpha_{0}}
$$

with $Z=2$ for helium nucleus.

The ionization energy is the energy required to remove the two electrons of helium atom to infinity. Thus for the ground state

$$
